description: From Middle English fotman, footman, foteman (“foot soldier, running footman”), from Old English *fōtman, *fōtmann (attested only as Old English fēþman, fēþmann (“footman”), equivalent to foot +‎ man.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A soldier who marches and fights on foot; a foot soldier.
A man in waiting; a male servant whose duties are to attend the door, the carriage, the table, etc.
(historical) A servant who runs in front of his master's carriage.
A metallic stand with four feet, for keeping anything warm before a fire.

definitionGroups.group: A moth of the family Arctiidae (or subfamily Arctiinae); -- so called from its livery-like colors.

entries.meaning: A bar that connects the treadle of a spinning wheel to the wheel.
